Hi Sue, nice to hear from you. This is a Naval dagger, a dress dagger 
that was worn by Japanese Naval Officers. They sometime came with 
genuine tanto in them, perhaps a family heirloom the office wanted to 
carry into battle, but mostly they came with a mass produce blade which 
was for the most part practical as a weapon, but not genuine Nihonto 
(traditionally made Japanese sword).

Tell the group where you are (state/city) and perhaps someone close by 
can have a look for you ?

A quick look here will give you a little more info
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/dirks.htm 
<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Esteinrl/dirks.htm>

Hope that helps just a little

cheers

Richard

sueb262 wrote:
>  
>
> Hi, all!
>
> I've been a "lurker" here for quite a while, just so I could learn a 
> little from listening to the conversations (which I have, thanks!), 
> but now I have a question of my own.
>
> When my uncle was billeted with a Japanese family during the 
> occupation, they gave him a tanto. My uncle is now gone, but I have 
> come into possession of that tanto. However, I don't know anything 
> about it, although I'm trying to find someone to whom I could take it 
> who would know how to identify/analyze it (no luck yet).
>
> I wonder if any of you could take the time to look at the pictures I 
> have of it and tell me what you can about it? I'd appreciate any 
> info/ideas about how old it is, what "school" it might be from (if 
> any), or anything else.
>
> Here's the link to my flickr account:
>
> http://www.flickr.com/photos/73941163@N00/?saved=1 
> <http://www.flickr.com/photos/73941163@N00/?saved=1>
>
> I'd appreciate any thoughts. Thanks!
>
> Sue
>
>
